» About Us

Spring Arbor University has 4 radio stations that make up Spring Arbor University Radio. They all operate on the campus of Spring Arbor University a set broadcast and production studios, and are a part of the university. SAU Radio began in a small house that was located on Cottage Street in Spring Arbor, and later moved to Sayre Decan on SAU’s main campus.

KTGG & WJKN-AM
These are our AM stations, at 1540 and 1510 AM. They are used for teaching beginning students with their very first experience on the air.

WSAE-FM
This is our signature station. It’s HOME.fm, and run by a professional and student radio staff all day long, with family-friendly programming and “Music That Makes You Feel Good”. HOME.fm started on Wednesday, May 18, 2005.

radio_info.short: The 100,000 watt powerhouse WHSB, known as “107.7 The Bay”, features the best contemporary music of the 80’s, 90’s and now, including adult pop songs
radio_info.rest:
from artists like Maroon 5, Nickelback, Gwen Stefani, Daughtry, Coldplay, Pink, 3 Doors Down, and Bon Jovi.

107.7 The BAY’s lineup includes Darrel Kelly with a light-hearted morning show filled with humor, trivia and upto date news with Phil Heimerl. Midday offers a music-heavy mix of the best of the 80’s 90’s and now for your workday. Mary Thurston is on the air from 2 until 6 pm every weekday afternoon. She plays your favorite songs, discusses the news with Ray McDade, officiates the Afternoon Trivia Bowl, and puts on her Cupcake Queen crown every Thursday for the “Cupcake Recipe of the Week”.

Contact The Bay at thebay@truenorthradionetwork.com .

WHSB is unsurpassed in community involvement, up-to-date news and weather, and listener promotions. It’s your music, your station!

radio_info.short: WCBN is the University of Michigan student-run community freeform radio station in Ann Arbor, Michigan. We broadcast at 200 watts to the University and its
radio_info.rest:
surrounding communities from the Basement of the Student Activities Building in downtown treetown. We are governed by our Constitution. 

Our emphasis is on alternative broadcasting, that is, exposing our listenership to things they can't hear on other radio stations. For more information about what we play, check out our Programming Department. 

You might want to read some of our Program Guide articles. Our Program Guide is published once a semester; sometimes as a poster and sometimes as a 16 or 24-page booklet. 

We have some history of the Network available on-line -- we've been around for over 50 years in one form or another, so our history is quite extensive. 

And for those of you who are tech heads, check out our facilities / equipment list. 

About this web site
Our web site was born soon after the first Mosaic was released. Since then, it has gone through lots of revisions. The current site was designed by Katie Linden. If you have questions or comments about this web site, please direct them to web AT wcbn DOT org

radios.title: Orchard Radio

radio_info.short: For over 40 years, WCC’s open-door admissions policy, affordable tuition rates, and high-quality classes have attracted students from local communities and around the world. More
radio_info.rest:
than 18,000 register for credit classes each year, and thousands more enroll in non-credit LifeLong Learning classes. WCC’s diverse student body includes more than 1,000 students from over 100 foreign countries.
WCC’s small classes allow for lots of individual attention. The average class size is 22 students. That’s a fraction of the size of many basic classes at four-year colleges and universities.
WCC also emphasizes convenience. It offers classes seven days a week, at night, and online. And transferring is easy because WCC has agreements with four-year schools throughout Michigan.

------

radios.title: Detroit Public Radio - WDET-FM

radio_info.short: WDET’s national and international programming offers the best in news, music, opinion and entertainment. WDET’s role in supporting the city is to share the truth
radio_info.rest:
of what the station’s listeners live every day through diverse perspectives, strengthening Detroit’s social fabric and community development by promoting civic and government transparency and accountability.  The WDET schedule is designed to strengthen the station’s local relevance, broaden and deepen the audience service and add several hours of compelling live, interactive programming on the weekday schedule and creative, Detroit-centric music shows on the weekend.  The current programming reflects the ideas, musical tastes and attitudes that characterize the city and its people, mirroring Detroit’s unique tone, style and approach. It also propels WDET into the national arena with fresh talk-show formats that give Detroiters a more prominent voice to share their story with the world. This local/national combination enables WDET listeners to feed their thoughts and experiences into the programming and give our area a new voice in the national dialogue.

------
Shows: All Things Considered, Car Talk (NPR), Fresh Air (NPR), Marketplace, NPR's Morning Edition, On the Media, Tavis Smiley Show, The Treatment, This American Life, Wait Wait, Don't Tell Me, Weekend Edition Saturday, Weekend Edition Sunday, From Our Own Correspondent (R4 Edition), Global Business, One Planet, The Strand, Assignment, BBC Business Daily, BBC World Business News, BBC World News, Charlie Gillett's World of Music, Heart and Soul, On Point, The Interview, The World Today, World Briefing, Speaking of Faith, Fresh Air Weekend, Tell Me More, The Business (KCRW), The Takeaway, Ann Delisi's Essential Music, Arkansas Traveler, Deep River, Destination Jazz, Detroit Today, Evolution of Jazz, Folks Like Us, Jay's Place, Michael Julien's Global Mix

radios.title: WDET-HD2

radio_info.short: Detroit's News Station with Great Music on the Weekend Public radio is independent media, an alternative to business or government-owned mass media. Providing programming unavailable
radio_info.rest:
on any other radio station in metropolitan Detroit, WDET 101.9 FM is licensed by the Federal Communications Commission to Wayne State University, owned and operated since 1952 to serve in the public interest.  WDET’s growing audience reaches more than 150,000 listeners every week in southeast Michigan, northwest Ohio and southwest Ontario.

WDET is a community nonprofit institution, actively involved in the life of metro Detroit. The station is the area’s most active promoter of the area’s music and is today one of the few remaining providers of local news. In addition, WDET’s national and international programming offers the best in news, music, opinion and entertainment. 

WDET’s role in supporting the city is to share the truth of what the station’s listeners live every day through diverse perspectives, strengthening Detroit’s social fabric and community development by promoting civic and government transparency and accountability.  The WDET schedule is designed to strengthen the station’s local relevance, broaden and deepen the audience service and add several hours of compelling live, interactive programming on the weekday schedule and creative, Detroit-centric music shows on the weekend.  The current programming reflects the ideas, musical tastes and attitudes that characterize the city and its people, mirroring Detroit’s unique tone, style and approach. It also propels WDET into the national arena with fresh talk-show formats that give Detroiters a more prominent voice to share their story with the world. This local/national combination enables WDET listeners to feed their thoughts and experiences into the programming and give our area a new voice in the national dialogue.

------
Shows: Piano Jazz, Riverwalk Jazz, The Thistle & Shamrock, From the Top, World Cafe, American Routes, Saint Paul Sunday, Mountain Stage, Jazz Set, Sound Opinions, Broadway Revisited, Sing Out, Studio 97

-----
Hosts: Not Found, David Holt, Jim Cullum, Christopher O'riley, Ji Yong Kim, Des Moines, Dennis Coffey, Lloyd Cole, Steve Miller, Nick Spitzer, Maureen Loughran, Kaori Maeyama, Bill Mcglaughlin, Larry Groce, Larry Kelp.

radios.title: Best Variety of Gospel Music - WFLT

radio_info.short: WFLT is one of the oldest stations in the market. It is over 55 years old and has maintained a loyal audience over the years.
radio_info.rest:
The community has taken ownership of WFLT, it being the only community-owned gospel station in the market. WFLT stands for What Flint Listens To, the #1 community-owned gospel station in Flint, Michigan.

In 1990 a group of local pastors formed CEBA, the Christian Evangelical Broadcasting Association. CEBA purchased WFLT because they felt the African-American community needed a voice, and a vehicle to be heard.
WFLT offers a seat on the front pew of the African-American church- the historic platform for all social and political change. The WFLT gospel format gives an advertiser an adult demographic from ages 25-75 who remain loyal to products and services that advertise on Christian radio. At WFLT, we are a station that stands for integrity, and the empowerment of the African-American community.

radio_info.short: WYVN (92.7 FM, "The Van") is a radio station broadcasting a classic hits format licensed to Saugatuck, Michigan, with studios in Holland, Michigan and is
radio_info.rest:
owned along with WHTC by Midwest Communications.

The station began operations on July 4, 1987 as WEVS. WEVS' music format consisted of a hybrid of rock and pop oldies dating back to the 1950s and current adult contemporary chart hits. During this time, the station was known as "The Lakeshore's Music Station," playing "Your Favorites of Five Decades."

In January 2001 Midwest Communications, Inc. began operating WEVS under a local marketing agreement. On April 9, 2001, after a weekend of stunting with a reading of last names from the Holland telephone directory beginning with "Van," WEVS relaunched as classic hits WYVN, "The Van." In October 2001, the station was purchased by Midwest Communications, bringing it into common ownership with Holland's longtime AM station, WHTC.

In early October 2007, Michiguide.com reported that WYVN had adjusted its playlist from classic hits to oldies/classic hits. The station moved back to a classic hits approach on December 30, 2008. It utilizes Dial Global/Jones Radio Network's Classic Hits format outside of the local morning show.

WHTC News Director Gary Stevens provides local news updates during the morning show.

radio_info.short: OFTEN MY DAUGHTER-IN-LAW ROBYN WILL SARCASTICALLY ASK MY 5 YEAR OLD GRANDSON ELI THE FOLLOWING QUESTION. R U SERIOUS? STATED ANOTHER WAY, DO YOU MEAN
radio_info.rest:
IT?


    OVER 60 YEARS AGO HIS HEAVENLY FATHER ASKED WFUR FOUNDER WILLIAM KUIPER SR. THE SAME QUESTION. HIS ANSWER, AS SERIOUS AS A HEART ATTACK. HE SOLD HIS CLOTHING STORE, INVESTED ALL HE HAD BOTH PHYSICALLY AND FINANCIALLY. CHRISTIAN RADIO FOR ALL PRACTICAL PURPOSES BECAME A REALITY. PERHAPS YOUR RESPONSE IS THAT’S NICE OR EVEN WHO CARES? STILL TODAY GOD ASKS THE QUESTION R U SERIOUS ABOUT ME.

    SOME RADIO STATIONS ARE VERY SERIOUS ABOUT POLITICS. THEY GO FOR HOURS EVERYDAY COMPLAINING, ARGUING, DEBATING POLITICS. WHAT ABOUT YOU, ARE YOU SERIOUS ABOUT POLITICS?
    OTHER RADIO STATIONS SING AND TALK PLEASURE. IF YOU DRINK, SMOKE AND DIVORCE YOU WILL BE A HAPPY NARCISSUS. HOW ABOUT YOU, ARE YOU ABOUT PLEASURE?

    STILL OTHER RADIO PROGRAMS ARE ALL ABOUT MONEY AND WEALTH. HOW TO FIND IT, LOOSE IT, KEEP IT. YOU ARE WHAT YOU OWN. ARE YOU SERIOUS ABOUT WEALTH AND POSSESSIONS?

    THERE ARE RADIO STATIONS THAT ARE SERIOUS ABOUT NEWS. WE’VE GOT YOUR ACCIDENTS, INCIDENTS AND ENTERTAINMENT NEWS. ARE YOU SERIOUS ABOUT NEWS? WHAT ABOUT THE GOOD NEWS?

    WE ARE GRATEFUL TO GOD AND TO THE PROGRAMS WHO SUPPORT THIS MINISTRY. WE ASK OUR LISTENERS TO WRITE OR CONTACT AND FINANCIALLY SUPPORT THE PROGRAMS HEARD ON WFUR CHRISTIAN RADIO. ALSO, CONSIDER BUYING FROM THE BUSINESSES THAT ADVERTISE WITH US.

    WE ARE THANKFUL FOR OUR ADVERTISERS, WHO ARE CRITICAL TO US CONTINUING. IF YOU OWN A BUSINESS AND ARE SERIOUS ABOUT FOLLOWING JESUS, PLEASE HELP US ENCOURAGE AND TELL OTHERS ABOUT HIM. THE REASON (PURPOSE) WFUR CONTINUES IS TO DO WHAT JESUS COMMANDED. HE THAT BELIEVETH IN ME HATH EVERLASTING LIFE. (JOHN 6:47)

radio_info.short: We are a Part 15 low power AM station serving the central portion of the community of Livonia, Michigan. Livonia is a western suburb of
radio_info.rest:
Detroit.  Our intention is play royalty free (real) jazz music and Old Time Radio programs.  You rarely here real jazz these days. I'm talking about "real" jazz, not "smooth" jazz.  We also like science fiction and science based programming.

This is not a community radio station.  We do not take requests or feel the need to provide a voice to promote any cause, no matter how noble or worthy. This is merely an expression of the hobbyist interests of the owner.  We hope you like our program choices.  If not, that's all right too.

This is not a pirate station. It is legally set up to conform to the rules set by Part 15 of the FCC rules.

radio_info.short: WKLA and WKLA-FM are a pair of co-owned radio stations broadcasting from Ludington, Michigan. The AM station went on the air on October 8, 1944,
radio_info.rest:
originally housed on the second floor of the Masonic Temple in downtown Ludington. Karl L. Ashbacher was the original owner, with his initials being the original basis for the call letters. (Previously the family had operated WKBZ in Ludington from 1926 to 1934, moving it to Muskegon, Michigan in the latter year.) In 1945 the WKLA studio moved to the Ludington Chamber of Commerce office at 204 E. Ludington Avenue. Raymond A. Plank purchased the station in 1949. In 1951, the station was moved to its current site at 5941 W. US 10 in Ludington. In 1971, WKLA expanded its programming with WKLA-FM.

Other past owners of WKLA include Tom Plank and Chickering & Associates. In 1996, the station was purchased by Roger Baerwolf under the corporate name of Lake Michigan Broadcasting, Inc. Today, the company owns and operates WKLA AM/FM, WMTE AM/FM (Manistee) and WKZC-FM (Scottville).

WKLA-FM plays Hot Adult Contemporary music; its 4,900-watt signal at 106.3 MHz can be heard from Kaleva, Michigan in the north to Hart, Michigan in the south. WKLA operates at 1450 kHz with 1,000 watts of power and airs oldies music.

radios.title: Mint City Radio
radios.profile_slogan: Internet Radio from the Palm of Michi

radio_info.short: Mint City Radio is Mid-Michigan's full-service internet radio station, featuring a variety of programming, local information, entertaining and informative features, and Super Hits of the
radio_info.rest:
60's, 70's and 80's.  You can listen to Mint City Radio live 24 hours a day, 7 days a week by clicking here.

Mint City Radio began in 2004 as Clinton County Radio, the first and only internet radio station dedicated to serving the 65,000 people who live and work in Clinton county, Michigan.  Clinton County Radio changed its name to WOAP Online in July 2008, and finally, we became Mint City Radio in June 2009.  Although our focus has expanded to include Ionia, Shiawassee and Gratiot counties, our commitment remains the same, our commitment remains the same - to provide a truly local radio station via the technology of the internet.

Mint City Radio features a variety of special programs throughout the week, including Radio's Golden Days, Jim Stone's Big Band Swing and Into Tomorrow with Dave Graveline.  You can also hear coverage of special events throughout the year, such as the Elsie Dairy Festival Parade, the St. Johns Mint Festival Parade, the Ovid Carriage Days Parade, the St. Johns Santa Parade and the Clinton County 4-H and Youth Fair.
